sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving aqueous solutions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the following reaction at 298 K: 

2NaHCO3(s) + MgCl2(aq) → MgCO3(s) + 2NaCl(aq) + H2O(l)

Given the following standard enthalpies of formation: 

ΔHf°(NaHCO3) = -950.7 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(MgCl2) = -641.8 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(MgCO3) = -1128.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(NaCl) = -411.2 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ [ΔHf°(products)] - Σ [ΔHf°(reactants)]

For the reactants:
2 moles of NaHCO3: 2 * (-950.7 kJ/mol) = -1901.4 kJ
1 mole of MgCl2: 1 * (-641.8 kJ/mol) = -641.8 kJ

For the products:
1 mole of MgCO3: 1 * (-1128.2 kJ/mol) = -1128.2 kJ
2 moles of NaCl: 2 * (-411.2 kJ/mol) = -822.4 kJ
1 mole of H2O: 1 * (-285.8 kJ/mol) = -285.8 kJ

Now, we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH°(reaction) = [(-1128.2) + (-822.4) + (-285.8)] - [(-1901.4) + (-641.8)]
ΔH°(reaction) = (-2236.4) - (-2543.2)
ΔH°(reaction) = 306.8 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction at 298 K is 306.8 kJ.
